Description: The SEC brought and settled civil administrative fraud charges against ten Wall Street and regional brokerage firms for overcharging municipalities for government securities in a practice commonly known as yield burning.

The National Credit Union Administration, on behalf of U.S. Central Federal Credit Union and Western Corporate Federal Credit Union, received $445 million from UBS for claims arising from losses related to purchases of residential mortgage-backed securities by those corporate credit unions.

The National Credit Union Administration announced that UBS would pay $69.8 million in damages and interest for claims arising from losses to Members United and Southwest, two corporate credit unions that failed during the financial crisis, related to purchases of residential mortgage-backed securities.
back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: As part of a deferred prosecution agreement, UBS AG  agreed to immediately provide the United States government with the identities of, and account information for, certain United States customers of UBS's cross-border business. UBS also agreed to expeditiously exit the business of providing banking services to United States clients with undeclared accounts. UBS further agreed to pay $780 million in fines, penalties, interest and restitution.

UBS agreed to pay $200 million to settle allegations that it facilitated the ability of certain U.S. clients to maintain undisclosed accounts in Switzerland and other foreign countries, which enabled those clients to avoid paying income taxes.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced an Order against UBS AG and UBS Securities Japan Co. settling charges of manipulation, attempted manipulation and false reporting of certain global benchmark interest rates.
The Federal Reserve announced it will impose fines totaling more than $1.8 billion against six major banking organizations for their unsafe and unsound practices in the foreign exchange markets.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission settled charges against Citibank N.A., HSBC Bank plc, JPMorgan Chase Bank N.A., The Royal Bank of Scotland plc and UBS AG for attempted manipulation of, and for aiding and abetting other banks' attempts to manipulate, global foreign exchange (FX) benchmark rates to benefit the positions of certain traders.

UBS AG agreed to plead guilty to manipulating the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) and other benchmark interest rates and pay a $203 million criminal penalty, after breaching its December 2012 non-prosecution agreement resolving the LIBOR investigation.

UBS AG entered into an agreement with the Department of Justice to resolve anticompetitive activity in the municipal bond investments market and has agreed to pay a total of $160 million in restitution, penalties and disgorgement to federal and state agencies.

UBS, without admitting to any allegations, consented to the issuance of the Order in connection with U.S. dollar banknote transactions with counterparties in jurisdictions subject to sanctions under U.S. law, specifically Cuba, Libya, Iran, and Yugoslavia.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that UBS AG agreed to pay $19.5 million to settle charges that it made false or misleading statements and omissions in offering materials provided to U.S. investors in structured notes linked to a proprietary foreign exchange trading strategy.

The U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control announced a $1,700,100 settlement with UBS AG to settle its potential civil liability for 222 apparent violations of the Global Terrorism Sanctions Regulations.

The SEC sanctioned 13 firms for violating a rule primarily designed to protect retail investors in the municipal securities market. In its surveillance of trading in the municipal bond market, the SEC Enforcement Division's Municipal Securities and Public Pensions Unit detected improper sales below a $100,000 minimum denomination set in a $3.5 billion offering of junk bonds by the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.
The SEC announced enforcement and disciplinary actions against a total of 15 firms for failure to deliver mutual fund breakpoint discounts during 2001 and 2002.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced a settlement of allegations that UBS Securities violated securities laws while structuring and marketing a collateralized debt obligation by failing to disclose that it retained millions of dollars in upfront cash it received in the course of acquiring collateral for the CDO.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced the separate filings and simultaneous settlements of charges against Morgan Stanley Capital Group, Inc. and UBS Securities Inc. in connection with Morgan Stanley's alleged concealment from the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) the existence of a large Trade at Settlement (TAS) block crude oil trade. UBS Securities allegedly aided and abetted that concealment.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that a subsidiary of UBS would pay $14.4 million to settle allegations relating to disclosure failures and other securities law violations linked to the operation and marketing of its dark pool.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that UBS Securities LLC would pay $8 million to settle allegations involving the execution of short sales.

The SEC -- along with the New York Attorney General, the North American Securities Administrators Association, NASD, the New York Stock Exchange and state securities regulators -- announced the completion of enforcement actions against ten of the nation's top investment firms joint investigations of allegations of undue influence of investment banking interests on securities research at brokerage firms.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: The Federal Housing Finance Agency announced a settlement with UBS Americas, Inc. for $885 million resolving alleged violations of federal and state securities laws in connection with private-label residential mortgage-backed securities purchased by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

Company: UBS Financial Services Inc. of Puerto Rico
Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced a settlement with UBS Financial Services Inc. of Puerto Rico and two executives concerning allegations of making misleading statements to investors, concealing a liquidity crisis, and masking control of the secondary market for 23 proprietary closed-end mutual funds.

Company: UBS Financial Services Inc. of Puerto Rico
Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged UBS Financial Services Inc. of Puerto Rico and a former branch manager for failing to supervise a former broker who had customers invest in UBSPR affiliated mutual funds using money borrowed from a UBSPR affiliated bank.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that an investment advisory arm of UBS settled allegations of failing to properly price securities in three mutual funds that it managed, resulting in a misstatement to investors of the net asset values of those funds.

UBS Securities Japan Co. Ltd. (UBS Japan), an investment bank, financial advisory securities firm and wholly-owned subsidiary of UBS AG, agreed to plead guilty to felony wire fraud and admit its role in manipulating the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR), a leading benchmark used in financial products and transactions around the world. UBS Japan has signed a plea agreement with the government admitting its criminal conduct, and has agreed to pay a $100 million fine. In addition, UBS AG, the parent company of UBS Japan headquartered in Zurich, has entered into a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with the government requiring UBS AG to pay an additional $400 million penalty, to admit and accept responsibility for its misconduct as set forth in an extensive statement of facts and to continue cooperating with the Justice Department in its ongoing investigation.

Company: UBS Willow Management LLC and UBS Fund Advisor LLC
Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that two UBS advisory firms agreed to settle charges arising from their roles in failing to disclose a change in investment strategy by UBS Willow Fund LLC, a closed-end fund they advised.

The SEC brought and settled civil administrative fraud charges against ten Wall Street and regional brokerage firms for overcharging municipalities for government securities in a practice commonly known as yield burning.
overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Hernandez et al v. UBS AG et al

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Landin et al v. UBS Services USA Llc et al

Company: UBS as successor to Piper Jaffray
Description: misclassification
Private Litigation Case Title: Gerry McNerney, et al. v. Piper Jaffray & Co., et al. and Jonathan Chaet v. Piper Jaffray Companies, et al.

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Bowman v. UBS Financial Services, Inc.

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Glass et al v. UBS Financial Services Inc. et al

Description: overtime violation
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 522320: Financial Transactions Processing, Reserve, and Clearinghouse Activities
Info Source: August 24, 2018 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Private Litigation Case Title: Nelson v. UBS Global Asset Management

Description: UBS consented to a penalty of $14.5 million, $9 million of which was to be satisfied by related penalties imposed by the SEC and FINRA.
Agency: Treasury Department Financial Crimes Enforcement Network

Description: In a case brought by the Michigan AG on behalf of state pension funds as well as other investors, UBS agreed to pay $117 million to settle allegations that its stock analyst reports did not present an honest assessment of the financial condition of HealthSouth Corporation, causing harm to shareholders.

UBS AG paid $68 million to settle multistate litigation alleging fraudulent and anticompetitive conduct involving the manipulation of LIBOR--a benchmark interest rate that affects financial instruments worth trillions of dollars and has a widespread impact on global markets and consumers.

UBS AG paid $90.8 million to settle multistate charges of anticompetitive and fraudulent conduct in the municipal bond derivatives industry, which took the form of bid-rigging, submission of non-competitive courtesy bids and submission to government agencies, among others, of fraudulent certifications of compliance with U.S. Treasury regulations. This was part of a larger $160 million settlement that also included federal agencies: https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-ubs-ag
market timing
UBS agreed to pay more than $4 million to settle multistate litigation that resulted from unregistered personnel accepting orders for the purchase and sale of securities.
UBS agreed to pay $70,077 in settlement of allegations it failed to ensure that its agents were properly registered in Delaware and other states.

UBS agreed to pay $23.3 million to settle allegations that it placed thousands of traditional brokerage customers to InsightOne accounts, falsely promising comprehensive and sophisticated financial planning services.

Company: UBS Financial Services, Inc. and UBS Securities LLC
Description: UBS agreed to return the funds invested by various Massachusetts town, cities and government entities in Auction Rate Securities. This was in settlement of allegations UBS misled the investors that the securities were permissable investments under Massachusetts law.

The New York Attorney General announced a $230 million settlement with UBS in connection with the packaging, marketing, sale, and issuance of residential mortgage-backed securities to investors in the period leading up to the financial crisis. The settlement included $189 million in consumer relief for New York homeowners and communities and $41 million in cash to New York State.
misrepresentation of mortgage-backed securities

Company: UBS Securities LLC and UBS Financial Services, Inc
Description: failure to disclose the risks of auction-rate securities

Company: UBS Securities LLC and UBS Financial Services, Inc.
Description: UBS agreed to buy back $11 billion in securities and pay $150 million in penalties as part of the resolution of multistate litigation alleging it misled customers in the marketing and sale of auction rate securities.

Ten major brokerage houses agreed to take steps to address conflicts of interest in their securities research work and pay $1.3 billion in penalties to settle multistate litigation. The penalties were also announced later by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission after it had approved the settlements; see the Violation Tracker entry for UBS Warburg at: https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-ubs-warburg-llc

Four financial firms agreed to pay a total of $1.3 million to West Virginia to settle allegations they engaged in bid-rigging in the municipal securities market. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the four companies.
Info Source: 4 financial groups settle $1.3M West Virginia antitrust case, Associated Press State & Local, August 29, 2016 (via Nexis).

Description: UBS Securities agreed to pay $733,465 to resolve allegations that it failed to properly warn investors about the risks of auction-rate securities.
Agency: Alaska Division of Banking and Securities

Description: Multi-state litigation. Penalty amount is share of total going to Alaska.
Agency: Alaska Division of Banking and Securities

Description: UBS Financial Services agreed to pay a $1.5 million fine, $1.25 million to the Connecticut Department of Education, $1 million to the Connecticut Department of Higher Education, $1.5 million to the Connecticut Department of Social Services, all for promotion of financial literacy, and $250,000 to the National White Collar Crime Center, in settlement of allegations it failed to supervise its agents, allowing them to engage in Market Timing, a prohibited practice of trading in mutual funds to exploit pricing inefficiencies.
Agency: Connecticut Securities and Business Investments Division

Description: UBS agreed to pay a $450,000 penalty and costs of $227,000 in settlement of allegations it failed to supervise the suitability of Funds it invested for the Indiana State Teachers Association Insurance Trust.

UBS agreed to pay $247,680 in restitution, $135,946 in disgorgement of commissions, $75,000 in civil penalties, $8,584 in costs and $230,000 to the Investor Education and Protection Fund in settlement of allegations it failed to adequately supervise two agents who were alleged to have dishonestly promoted unsuitable investments to customers.

UBS agreed to pay up to $4,503,166 in restitution (unclaimed restitution would revert to the company) in settlement of allegations actions that representatives of the company had caused losses for investors.

Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation

Description: UBS agreed to pay a $6.64 million fine to Texas to settle a case involving investors who were misled about the safety of auction-rate securities and who were left out of a 2008 nationwide settlement.
UBS agreed to pay $4.6 million to settle multistate litigation alleging it failed to make sure that its client service associates were licensed and in compliance with state regulations.

Company: UBS Securities LLC and UBS Financial Services Inc.
Description: UBS agreed to pay $75 million to a group of states and another $75 million to New York State to resolve allegations that it failed to properly warn investors about the risks of auction-rate securities. The settlement was also announced by the New York Attorney General; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-ubs-securities-llc-and-ubs-financial-ser

UBS agreed to pay $25 million to a group of states to settle allegations that its investment banking interests had undue influence on its securities research. This was part of a larger $80 million settlement involving the SEC; see the Violation Tracker https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-ubs-warburg-llc
UBS Financial Services Inc. agreed to pay $10 million to resolve allegations that it circumvented the priority given to retail investors in certain municipal bond offerings.

Agency: Connecticut Department of Energy & Environmental Protection
Notes: Captured from summaries produced by DEP; may not include full details of penalties.

Description: FINRA censured and fined UBS Financial Services Inc. $2 million for the firm's repeated failures in timely addressing municipal short positions and in inaccurately representing the tax status of thousands of interest payments to customers. FINRA also required UBS to pay restitution to customers who may have incurred any increased state tax liabilities, to pay the IRS to relieve customers of any additional federal income tax owed, and to certify within 90 days that the firm has taken appropriate corrective measures.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Company: UBS Financial Services Inc. and UBS Securities LLC
Description: FINRA fined UBS Financial Services Inc. (UBSFS) $4.5 million and UBS Securities LLC (UBSS) $500,000 for failing to establish and implement anti-money laundering programs reasonably designed to monitor certain high-risk transactions in customer accounts. The high-risk transactions included foreign currency wire transfers at UBSFS, and transactions in low-priced equity securities, or penny stocks, at UBSS.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Company: UBS Financial Services Incorporated of Puerto Rico
Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority censured and fined UBS Financial Services Incorporated of Puerto Rico (UBS PR) $7.5 million for supervisory failures related to the suitability of transactions in Puerto Rican closed-end fund (CEF) shares. In addition, FINRA ordered UBS PR to pay approximately $11 million in restitution to 165 customers who were forced to realize losses on their CEF positions.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority sanctioned Citigroup Global Markets, Inc; Morgan Stanley & Co., LLC; UBS Financial Services; and Wells Fargo Advisors, LLC for selling leveraged and inverse exchange-traded funds (ETFs) without reasonable supervision and for not having a reasonable basis for recommending the securities.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined UBS Securities LLC $12 million for violating Regulation SHO and failing to properly supervise short sales of securities. As a result of these violations, millions of short sale orders were mismarked and/or placed to the market without reasonable grounds to believe that the securities could be borrowed and delivered.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined UBS Financial Services, Inc. $2.5 million and required UBS to pay $8.25 million in restitution for omissions and statements made that effectively misled some investors regarding the principal protection feature of 100% Principal-Protection Notes (PPNs) Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. issued prior to its September 2008 bankruptcy filing.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Citigroup Global Markets, UBS Securities and Deutsche Bank Securities a total of $425,000 - and ordered the firms to make payments to customers that could total $420,000 - in connection with the firms' failure to adequately supervise communications with their customers in the initial public offering (IPO) of Vonage, LLC in May 2006.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. $150,000 and UBS Financial Services, Inc. $100,000 for supervisory failures that led to unsuitable short-term sales of closed-end funds (CEF) purchased at the funds' initial public offerings.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: FINRA settled cases against five firms for mutual fund sales and supervisory violations - including improper sales of Class B and Class C mutual fund shares and failure to have supervisory systems designed to provide all eligible investors with the opportunity to purchase Class A mutual fund shares at net asset value (NAV) through NAV transfer programs.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined 19 broker-dealers a total of $2.8 million for substantially overstating their advertised trade volume to three private service providers.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority censured and fined UBS Financial Services, Inc. $370,000, for making hundreds of late disclosures to FINRA's Central Registration Depository (CRD) of information about its brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions and criminal disclosures.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD censured and fined 20 securities firms a total of $1.65 million for late and/or inaccurate reporting of tens of thousands of municipal securities transactions to the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and imposed fines totaling more than $1.2 million on 18 firms for violations relating to NASD's Order Audit Trail (OATS) rules and supervision.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD ordered eight firms to pay fines totaling $310,000 and restitution to customers of $300,000 in connection with certain municipal bond trades where customers did not receive a fair price for their bonds, in violation of Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (MSRB) rules.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a settled action against UBS Financial Services Inc. for compliance failures relating to sales of a volatility linked exchange-traded product (ETP).

The Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an order simultaneously filing and settling charges against UBS AG, provisionally registered swap dealer, for failing to retain certain audio recordings for the time required under CFTC regulations. The order finds that as a result of failures in UBS's audio retention systems, the firm deleted over 1,000 hours of audio data after one day, including voice recording files that were required by CFTC regulations to be retained for one year. The order requires UBS to pay a $500,000 civil monetary penalty and to cease and desist from further violations of CFTC regulations, as charged.
